The past is a foreign country

content.html:
I tried watching a classic Western this weekend, How The West Was Won. I did not make it far. Let‚Äôs just say that in the first few minutes, the Spencer Tracy voiceover that accompanies the sweeping vistas sets out an attitude toward the indigenous population that would not fly today.

It‚Äôs one thing to be repulsed by a film from another era, but it‚Äôs even more uncomfortable to revisit the films from your own teenage years.

Tim Carmody has written about the real hero of Top Gun:

Iceman‚Äôs concern for Maverick and the safety of his fighter unit is totally understandable. He tries, however awkwardly, to discuss Goose‚Äôs death with Maverick. There‚Äôs no discussion of blame. And when they‚Äôre assigned to fly into combat together, Iceman briefly and discreetly raises the issue of Maverick‚Äôs fitness to fly with his superior officer and withdraws his concern once a decision is made.

I know someone who didn‚Äôt watch Ferris Bueller‚Äôs Day Off until they were well into adulthood. Their sympathies lay squarely with Dean Rooney.

And I think we can all agree in hindsight that Walter Peck was completely correct in his assessment of the dangers in Ghostbusters.

Oh, and The Karate Kid was the real bully.

This week, George wrote I‚Äôve fallen out of love with Indiana Jones. Indy‚Äôs attitude of ‚Äúit belongs in a museum‚Äù is the same worldview that got the Parthenon Marbles into the British Museum (instead of, y‚Äôknow, the Parthenon where they belong).

Adrian Hon invites us to imagine what it would be like if the tables were turned. He wrote a short piece of speculative fiction called The Taking of¬†Stonehenge:

We selected these archaeological sites based on their importance to our collective understanding of human and galactic history, and their immediate risk of irreparable harm from pollution, climate change, neglect, and looting. We are sympathetic to claims that preserving these sites in their ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù context is important, but our duty of care outweighs such emotional considerations.
content.value:

  Iceman‚Äôs concern for Maverick and the safety of his fighter unit is totally understandable. He tries, however awkwardly, to discuss Goose‚Äôs death with Maverick. There‚Äôs no discussion of blame. And when they‚Äôre assigned to fly into combat together, Iceman briefly and discreetly raises the issue of Maverick‚Äôs fitness to fly with his superior officer and withdraws his concern once a decision is made.


I know someone who didn‚Äôt watch Ferris Bueller‚Äôs Day Off until they were well into adulthood. Their sympathies lay squarely with Dean Rooney.

And I think we can all agree in hindsight that Walter Peck was completely correct in his assessment of the dangers in Ghostbusters.

Adrian Hon invites us to imagine what it would be like if the tables were turned. He wrote a short piece of speculative fiction called The Taking of¬†Stonehenge:


  We selected these archaeological sites based on their importance to our collective understanding of human and galactic history, and their immediate risk of irreparable harm from pollution, climate change, neglect, and looting. We are sympathetic to claims that preserving these sites in their ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù context is important, but our duty of care outweighs such emotional considerations.

content.html:
We use metaphors all the time. To quote George Lakoff, we live by them.

We use analogies some of the time. They‚Äôre particularly useful when we‚Äôre wrapping our heads around something new. By comparing something novel to something familiar, we can make a shortcut to comprehension, or at least, categorisation.

But we need a certain amount of vigilance when it comes to analogies. Just because something is like something else doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs the same.

With that in mind, here are some ways that people are describing generative machine learning tools. Large language models are like‚Ä¶

  • ‚Ä¶a blurry JPEG of the web,
  • ‚Ä¶fly-by-wire avionics,
  • ‚Ä¶drum machines,
  • ‚Ä¶an octopus.
content.value:
We use metaphors all the time. To quote George Lakoff, we live by them.

We use analogies some of the time. They‚Äôre particularly useful when we‚Äôre wrapping our heads around something new. By comparing something novel to something familiar, we can make a shortcut to comprehension, or at least, categorisation.

But we need a certain amount of vigilance when it comes to analogies. Just because something is like something else doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs the same.

With that in mind, here are some ways that people are describing generative machine learning tools. Large language models are like‚Ä¶


‚Ä¶a blurry JPEG of the web,
‚Ä¶fly-by-wire avionics,
‚Ä¶drum machines,
‚Ä¶an octopus.

content.html:
Those meddling kids! The Reverse Scooby-Doo theory of tech innovation comes with the excuses baked in | Nieman Journalism Lab

Manufactured inevitability a.k.a bullshit:

There‚Äôs a standard trope that tech evangelists deploy when they talk about the latest fad. It goes something like this:

  1. Technology XYZ is arriving. It will be incredible for everyone. It is basically inevitable.
  2. The only thing that can stop it is regulators and/or incumbent industries. If they are so foolish as to stand in its way, then we won‚Äôt be rewarded with the glorious future that I am promising.

We can think of this rhetorical move as a Reverse Scooby-Doo. It‚Äôs as though Silicon Valley has assumed the role of a Scooby-Doo villain ‚Äî but decided in this case that he‚Äôs actually the hero. (‚ÄúWe would‚Äôve gotten away with it, too, if it wasn‚Äôt for those meddling regulators!‚Äù)

The critical point is that their faith in the promise of the technology is balanced against a revulsion towards existing institutions. (The future is bright! Unless they make it dim.) If the future doesn‚Äôt turn out as predicted, those meddlers are to blame. It builds a safety valve into their model of the future, rendering all predictions unfalsifiable.
content.value:
Those meddling kids! The Reverse Scooby-Doo theory of tech innovation comes with the excuses baked in | Nieman Journalism Lab

  The only thing that can stop it is regulators and/or incumbent industries. If they are so foolish as to stand in its way, then we won‚Äôt be rewarded with the glorious future that I am promising.

If the future doesn‚Äôt turn out as predicted, those meddlers are to blame. It builds a safety valve into their model of the future, rendering all predictions unfalsifiable.

content.html:
Redefining Developer Experience ‚Äî Begin Blog

Perhaps most problematic of all is the effect that contemporary developer experience has on educational programs (be they traditional classes, bootcamps, workshops, or anything in between). Such a rapidly expanding and ever changing technological ecosystem necessarily means that curricula struggle to keep up, and that the fundamentals of web development (e.g. HTML, CSS, HTTP, browser APIs‚Ä¶) are often glossed over in favor of getting students into the technologies more likely to land them jobs (like React and its many pals). This leads to an outpouring of early career developers who may speak confidently about things like React hooks or Redux state reducers, but who also lack any concept about the nature of HTML semantics or the most basic accessibility considerations. To be clear, I‚Äôm not throwing shade at those developers ‚Äî they have been failed by an industry obsessed with the new and shiny at the expense of foundational practices and end user experiences.

And so, I ask: what exactly are we buying when we are sold ‚Äòdeveloper experience‚Äô today? Who is benefiting from it? And if it is indeed something many of us aren‚Äôt too excited about (to put it kindly), how can we change it for the better?

I agree with pretty much every word of this article.
content.value:

To be clear, I‚Äôm not throwing shade at those developers ‚Äî they have been failed by an industry obsessed with the new and shiny at the expense of foundational practices and end user experiences.

I agree with pretty much every word of this article.

content.html:
The Great Gaslighting of the JavaScript Era | The Spicy Web

We were told writing apps with an HTML-first, SSR-first, progressively enhanced mindset, using our preferred language/tech stack of choice, was outdated and bad for users.

That was a lie.

We were told writing apps completely using frontend-y JavaScript would make our lives easier.

That also was a lie.

I agree with pretty much every word of this article.
content.value:
The Great Gaslighting of the JavaScript Era | The Spicy Web




  We were told writing apps with an HTML-first, SSR-first, progressively enhanced mindset, using our preferred language/tech stack of choice, was outdated and bad for users.
  
  That was a lie.
  
  We were told writing apps completely using frontend-y JavaScript would make our lives easier.
  
  That also was a lie.


I agree with pretty much every word of this article.

name: The Great Gaslighting of the JavaScript Era | The Spicy Web

content.html:
On Container Queries, Responsive Images, and JPEG-XL ‚Äì Cloud Four

Container queries can‚Äôt be used in the sizes attribute for responsive images. Here, Jason breaks down why that is (spoiler: it‚Äôs the lookahead pre-parser) and segues into a truly long term solution: a ‚Äúmagical‚Äù image format.

If you‚Äôve ever thought it felt weird to put media conditions inside the HTML for responsive images, this will resonate.
content.value:

The next four speakers for UX London 2023

content.html:
I am positively giddy with excitement to tell you about some more speakers you can look forward to at UX London 2023:

  • Stacey Mendez, Product and Experience Designer,
  • Hannah Smith, Director of Operations at the Green Web Foundation,
  • Vitaly Friedman, Creative Lead at Smashing Magazine, and
  • Trine Falbe, Ethical Design Consultant at Falbe Consulting.

I have more confirmed speakers but I‚Äôm going to be a tease and save them for a separate announcement soon. You can expect more of the same: smart, fabulous people with all kinds of design experience that they‚Äôre going to share with you at UX London.

But why wait for another speaker announcement? Get your ticket to UX London 2023 now!

But why wait for another speaker announcement? Get your ticket to UX London 2023 now!
